item.title:
We discovered a surprisingly easy way to control the brightness of fluorescent proteins via magnetic fields:
https://t.co/zxPPsd14zP
This raises fascinating scientific questions about the mechanism, and tantalizing technological opportunities for bioengineering. https://t.co/4gBBpxrVsX

item.title:
But it turns out, mScarlet mixed with flavin (0.5 mM FMN) is ~2-3% dimmer in a ~10 mT magnetic field - a simple bio-compatible magetically-controlled protein machine!
Other fluorophores (including GFP!) and cofactors (e.g. cinnavalininate instead of flavin) work too. https://t.co/8ZihIcKmSJ

item.title:
FlavinTagged-GFP gives a convenient, robust biocompatible single-molecule magnetofluor (thanks @fraaije1!). Here it is blinking *inside* the mitochondria of a living COS7 cell!
The ~10 mT field is just a strong fridge magnet moved back and forth by an Arduino servo. https://t.co/H7xKxtW262

item.title:
New photophysics unlocks new inventions, like background rejection (blinking magnetofluors vs. nonblinking background) or multiplexing (different mutants equilibrate at different rates).
Long-term, we're dreaming of "magnetogenetics": magnetic control of optogenetic circuits! https://t.co/FO1YQnFBiz

item.title:
Different mutants have different magnetoresponse amplitude and rate. We haven't found an effect stronger than ~3% in proteins, but the Cohen work makes us hopeful that this isn't physically impossible.
We'd love to engineer the effect to be much stronger.

item.title: We've adapted a variant of the crystal skull preparation to target the entire dorsal cortex. This development completes our surgical capabilities for both 2p and Neuropixels. For instance, we can now record from the motor cortex with 2p and Neuropixels! https://t.co/UOsCIjhHxO
